I have no doubt that TDD works great on such simple =
problems and that it can
even lead to a reasonable design.  Then again, the=
 problem space is so small
that you can argue that no design will really be=
 wrong anyway...

Now consider a more realistic example, such as an applica=
tion that is
dealing with five database tables, each with four to ten colum=
ns, each of
which needs to be mapped to Java objects in a sensible way (i.e=
. not
necessarily mapping the tables and the objects one-to-one) and should=
 also
include business methods and objects to make it easier to perform
dom=
ain-specific operations.

Using TDD to drive such a design is guaranteed to=
 lead to an architecture
that will be focused on solving micro-problems and=
 that will totally miss
the big picture.  You are much better off spending =
a few minutes with a
piece of paper or a white board to design your classes=
 and your object
diagram.

If you want to use TDD to implement this model a=
fter that, fine, but I
really dispute the idea that TDD should drive the de=
sign in the general
case, because TDD simply never gives you the big pictur=
e.

Makes sense?
